div.p: 1. IV:15. Tuesday.

Charles went in to Boston, and did not come out at Night. At 11. O’Clock Mr Thomas Greenleaf called and took me in his Chaise to attend the annual Meeting of the Proprietors of Neponset Bridge which was held at the Public House on this side the Bridge— The members who besides myself attended were G. W. Beale—T. Greenleaf, Edward Miller and G. W. Wales— Mr
Greenleaf was re-elected Clerk, and G. W. Beale Treasurer and Superintendant, and sworn into Office by Mr Miller— The Directors of the last year were re-elected and we proceeded to Squantum, where at Mr Beale’s new Establishment we dined upon fish—being joined by Mr Daniel Greenleaf, my brother and W. Smith— Towards evening we returned, and I stopped to pass an hour at Mr D. Greenleaf’s, where were his brothers family, and Mrs Charles Appleton. On coming home I found Mr and Mrs Felt of Hamilton, who had come to pass the Night with us— Mr Felt is Minister at Hamilton, and his wife is a daughter and only surviving child of my Mother’s Sister Elizabeth, by her first husband John Shaw— They own in her right a house and Land in Medford, jointly with my brother, whose part has long been mortgaged to me, for much more than it is worth— A partition of it has lately been made of it between them; and Mr Felt wishes that the whole may be sold; to which I told him I should have no objection— While I was abroad this afternoon, Mr Andrew Coyle, of Washington was here— I wrote this morning a Letter in answer to one from Jared Sparks, and received his reply.
2. IV:30. Wednesday.

Mr Noah Curtis called this morning and paid me the interest upon the Note of the Parish to me, from its date 29. May 1827. to the first of October next— I told him I should wish only for payment of the Interest on the Note to the Executors of my father, and not the principal for the present. I promised to execute the Deed of the half Acre of Land at the foot of Penn’s Hill to his Son Samuel, and told him it had not been executed before, only because by Mr Quincy’s absence, I had not been able to cancel the mortgage upon the farm— He said my Warranty would be sufficient for his Son—and spoke of the partition fence which must be maintained jointly between us. He said also that White had called upon his Son to maintain half the fence between them— After breakfast I took a walk with Mr Felt to Mount Wollaston— He gave me three numbers of a Work, he is publishing under the title of Annals of Salem, and of which he told me there would be two more numbers. He mentioned a design to publish a great part of the Old Colony Records, a very good, but I thought a somewhat hazardous undertaking— Mr and Mrs Felt declined staying with us to dine, and were going from here to Medford. I had morning visits from Dr. Prince of Salem, and Dr Holbrook, and afterwards from Mr John Parker, who told me he was 72 years old, and a Mr Read of South Carolina—a nephew of Jacob Read once a member of Congress. Just before dinner I bathed, and swam between wharf and wharf—precisely 15 minutes— Charles came out to dine, and brought me Letters from my wife and Son, at Washington. 27. and 28. Augt. and one from C. Hughes at Bruxelles, with enclosures for General S. Smith of Baltimore— Also one from David Greenough requesting me to deliver to the order of the Trustees of the Boston Atheneum, my bust executed by his Son— It was sent to me by mistake. Much of the morning was absorbed by my visitors, and I barely made out to write my page of Memoirs— In the afternoon I read some pages of Hutchinson, and a few Letters in the third Volume of Madame du Deffand, which I still find very amusing. The day was sultry with a distant thunder-shower in the Evening.
3. IV.45. Thursday.— My Son Charles F. Adams, married to A. B. Brooks.

Morning visits from Mr Parkyns, heretofore a Sheriff of London, with Henry Gray; and from Mr and Mrs Fuller of Cambridge. Mr Parkyns is a personage of some notoriety, and of great abundance, and not a little singularity of Conversation— He shewed me a fowling piece loaded, disguised as a walking Stick, and a piece of an old Greek Manuscript, said to have been found in the City of Canopus— He told me also something of his controversies with James Buchanan the British Consul at New-York, and of monuments he has ordered to be erected to the Regicides Goffe and Whalley at New Haven— He has no reverence for the house of Stuart, and very little for the House of Brunswick Lunenberg. Charles took leave of the paternal mansion this Morning and went into Boston— At 1/2 past four this afternoon, I rode with T. B. Adams junr to Boston—stopp’d at Cary the Stone-Cutters—who not being at his work-yard, I left with his partner Dickinson, the Monumental inscription— Left a Note from Louisa Foster, to her Sister Mary, at her fathers house; and called to leave a parcel for Charles at his House; we then went over Craigie’s Bridge to Mr Peter C. Brooks’s at Medford, where my Son Charles was married by the Revd. Caleb Stetson, the Minister of the Parish, to Abigail Brown Brooks, youngest daughter of Peter Chardon Brooks, and of Anne, daughter of Nathaniel Gorham of Charlestown. They were married according to the Congregational form of worship; in presence of the father and mother of the bride— Of their Sons Edward, Peter Chardon junr. and Sidney Brooks and their wives—of their daughters Anne and her husband Edward Everett, and Charlotte, and her husband the Revd. N. L. Frothingham—of Mrs Stetson wife of the Minister—Edmund Quincy and Edward Blake, bridemen, Miss Carter and Miss Grey; bridemaids and of Miss Philips a niece of Mr Brooks, residing with him. There were also two boys sons of Mr Frothingham—Lieutenant T. B. Adams and myself— After the Ceremony there was a joyous supper— Charles and his bride went into Boston, to their own House, and the rest of the company went to their several homes; excepting Lieutenant T. B. Adams and myself, who by invitation of Mr and Mrs Brooks remained to pass the Night at Medford— Mrs Brooks is in declining health, and only by great exertion was able to attend the festive solemnity— May the blessing of God rest upon this marriage and upon the parties to it.
4. V:15. Friday— To Boston and Quincy.

This morning before Breakfast I took a walk with Mr Brooks round his garden and grounds, which are laid out with great neatness, to much utility; not without ornament; and although at great expense, with a very judicious economy. The Middlesex Canal forms a boundary to the Garden, and over it he has thrown a bridge of Granite which gives him the benefit of a Mile’s walk on the western border of the Canal. He has flourishing Thorn hedges, both Virginian and English; and the growth of the Native is far more luxuriant and healthy than that of the exotic. He has a great variety of flowers, an abundance of Water— A small green-house lately built, a Multitude of Trees; forest and fruit— Foreign and indigenous— And a few marble Statues from Italy. This and the prospects are the two points upon which I think the place susceptible of
improvement— There are many Country Seats in this Neighbourhood of more splendor, magnificence and expense— I wish there were one with indications of Mind and Morals— A large and valuable Library— Samples of painting and Sculpture, pregnant with Instruction— Interesting Portraits of our Countrymen, by native Artists. Historical Pictures illustrative of memorable events in our History— How much more could I say— But when will there be such a Country Seat in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts? Mr and Mrs Frothingham breakfasted with us— Mrs Brooks came down— Struggling to be cheerful, but drooping under an irrecoverable disease— After breakfast I came with my nephew to Boston. Stopped at Winter-Hill to call on Mr and Mrs Everett, but they were gone to Medford— At Boston I found Charles at his Office, with an affectionate Letter of congratulation from his brother— I began at Medford and finished at Boston one to my wife. I met in the Street Dr. George Parkman—who went with me to the Stone Chapel; where I inspected again the Monument to the Memory of Governor Shirley’s wife and daughter— I wished to take a copy of the Inscription, as it is on the Tablet; but Dr: Parkman told me he had one, of which he would send me a copy; which he afterwards did— I called at the House of the new married pair, in Hancock Avenue, and saw my daughter Abigail, a name most dear to me because it was that of my Mother and of my Sister. Miss Carter one of her bridemaids and Miss Gorham, a daughter of the late Doctor were there. I gave my daughter a Cameo ring with two hands joined for a wedding present— I afterwards called at Mr Benjamin Joy’s; but he was too ill to see me; and probably very near his end. His son Joseph Joy told me that he was very low, and could see no person but his physician— I went to the Stone cutters Cary and Dickinson, and saw Mr Cary. They have not yet received their Tablet; but Cary renewed his promise to have it ready to put up, by the first of October. At Mr James H. Foster’s I took a Note for Louisa; and taking up the Lieutenant at Charles’s Office, we came out to Quincy to dine— After dinner, a man named Rowe, came from the Athenaeum, with an order for my Bust, done by Greenough—which was delivered to him. I also sent by him Charles’s two trunks which he had left here— There was an Evening party at Mr T. Greenleaf’s which my Ladies attended— I spent the afternoon in writing, and the Evening in reading the pamphlet controversy between Dr Holmes of Cambridge and his Parish.
5. V. Saturday.

Dr Waterhouse came and dined with me, and brought back the Manuscript of my reply to the appeal of the Confederates. He thinks it ought to be published immediately; but I am more and more confirmed in the opinion that it should not— No great public interest now requires it— For my justification it may answer hereafter as well as now— While the Doctor was here—Mr Issaverden a Greek from Smyrna, brought me a Letter of Introduction from E. Wyer—with him were two young men from South Carolina—Mr Clark and a Doctor Elliot— Towards Evening I walked to my brothers, and spent a couple of hours with him and his family. His wife’s brother Charles Harrod was there, just arrived from New-Orleans; there were also there his three daughters. Mr Gourgas who boards at the house, and my brother’s Son Isaac; who has been hurt by falling into a cellar— After returning home I read a few Letters of Madame du Deffands, and had read some pages of Hutchinson’s History. I wrote this morning a Letter to my
son John, and in mentioning to him the Circumstance that Charles’s Marriage was on the anniversary of the definitive Treaty of Peace of 1783. it occurred to me that my father’s participation in that Treaty should be noticed on the monumental Inscription which I have prepared— Mr Peter Whitney called on me again on Thursday Morning, and was well satisfied with the Inscription, which I shewed him, but this addition to it would be a great improvement.
6. IV:45. Sunday.

Heard Mr Peter Whitney, in the morning from Matthew 9.13.— “I am not come to call the righteous, but sinners to repentance” and in the afternoon from 2. Peter 3.16—“In which are some things hard to be understood.” The morning discourse was a very earnest exhortation to repentance; with some anti-calvinistic doctrines; which are indeed so absurd, that Reason is ashamed of debating them— That of the afternoon, was one of a Series, explanatory of some of the things hard to be understood— Upon the same text, he had reviewed on the 5th. of July the Gospel of Matthew— This day his examination was of the Book of Luke. Why he passed over that of Mark, he did not inform us— He began by a short commendatory character of Luke’s gospel; said he was the most learned of the Evangelists—probably one of the disciples, who going to Emmaus, met Jesus after the Resurrection, and afterwards a companion of Paul. He noted all the parts of Luke’s narrative, not contained in any other of the Gospels.— The first passage which he cited as hard to be understood, was the forty days temptation of Jesus by the devil—which he gave it as his opinion was a Vision. The next was Chapter 5.20. where Jesus declares to the man whom he had cured of the palsy, that his sins were forgiven. Mr Whitney encountered the argument of this fact to the Godhead of Christ, rather feebly. The Scribes and Pharisees who heard the saying, cried out that it was blasphemy, and truly said who can forgive Sins but God? Jesus replies by healing the palsied man with a word, and asks the objectors which of the two miracles is the easiest? The power of suspending the Laws of physical nature was susceptible of Evidence to the Senses— The power of moral remission was to be inferred from it— But the power of performing miracles was exercised by Moses and the prophets— Yet they had not power upon earth to forgive Sins. Mr Whitney was not more successful in his commentary upon the demoniac Swine, or the seven Devils of Mary Magdalen. These are things yet hard to be understood— I read the 8th. and 9th. Sermons of Dr Freeman’s Volume—on the Marriage of Cana, and upon pardon to repentance— T. B. Adams junr. was here this Evening— His uncle Harrod, with his family left them this afternoon.
7. III.45. Monday.

Visits from Mrs Dexter, with her Son now here, but who resides in the Territory of Michigan, and his wife— I enquired of Mrs Dexter, how her Son Frankin was, upon which she asked to speak with me in private, and told me that she and her two other children were all mortified, at the part, which Franklin Dexter had taken with the Boston Confederates against me— She assured me that no other person of
her family thought or felt as he did, on that subject; that they lamented the course he had taken, and imputed it to the connections he had formed. She meant his marriage with a daughter of William Prescott, a member of the Hartford Convention. I told her I had made every allowance on that account— That I retained no resentment whatever against her Son, but had every kind feeling towards all her family that I had ever cherished. This afternoon at four O’Clock I went with Lieutenant T. B. Adams, and his Sister Abigail in to Boston— Stopp’d at the Stone-Cutters Cary and Dickinson; and left with Mr Cary, the revised Inscription for the Monument, in which I had made several alterations, and some addition— After leaving Thomas and Abigail at Mr N. H. Foster’s, I went to my Son Charles’s house, where they received company this Evening upon the occasion of their marriage. They have a small but very comfortable House; furnished with elegance. Their company besides the family relations, was not numerous; but was generally of cordial friends. The Chevalier Huygens, the Minister from the Netherlands, with his wife, and two daughters were there— Lieutenant Governor Winthrop, Mr Webster, Professor Ware with Mrs Ware were of the Company. Richard and Mrs Derby, and several whom I did not know. I gave F. C. Gray, a Letter to the Proprietors of the Boston Athenaeum; and asked Mr Sparks to come and dine with me at Quincy to-morrow which he promised he would do. It was near nine, when the company began to come, and by half past ten, all excepting the family had retired— We returned to Quincy, and reached home about half past eleven— Thomas and Abigail stopped for the Night with us— There is a fashionable formality in these wedding visits, and subsequent parties; different from the practice heretofore; and objectionable in many cases for its expensiveness. The Lady sends her Cards with her maiden name, and on the back of it at Home, such an Evening— The bridemen, introduce all the Visitors, to the bride with as much ceremony as at an European Court presentation— The dresses of the Ladies are too costly: and this wedding visit is succeeded by evening parties or dinners given by friends
8. VI. Tuesday.

Mr Brigham came this morning and brought me the Certificate of Share N. 34. in the Quincy Canal Corporation, which I had purchased of E. Chamberlin; and he also concluded to sell me three Notes of the Corporation, which he held, one of 210 one of 140. and one of 70 dollars; at the same price for which I purchased of Chamberlin— He wished me also to take two of his Shares, but was not yet willing to part with them at less than 75 dollars a Share— I take it for granted he will come down to 60— This is hazardous Speculation; and all my friends think it desperate— I hope it may prove otherwise— Mr Sparks came and dined with me— I shewed him all my father’s manuscript Letter Books, and told him they should be at his disposal, either to complete the publication of diplomatic correspondence authorised by Congress, or for the composition of his History— He has collected in France and England voluminous materials for that History, but I perceive by his Conversation, that he has become a partizan of Dr Franklin, and of the Count de Vergennes, in relation to the controversies of those Times. His motives have doubtless reference to himself, to the present and the future; I offered him the freest use of my father’s Letter books, but was somewhat more reserved with regard to his papers— I found it the more necessary to use this reserve after
ascertaining the bias he had taken. Towards Evening I took a walk across the Hills; and spent the Evening at Mr Marston’s— He beat me at Chess Mr Tyng one of the Sons of the late Dudley-Atkins-Tyng, was there— He is preaching at the episcopal church, supplying the place of Mr Cutler the settled minister, who is in ill health, and absent— It was midnight last Night when I retired to bed, and the Sun this morning rose before me— A corresponding chasm appears in the performance of my task. I wrote a very short Letter in answer to J. N. Reynolds—
9. IV.15. Wednesday—

Time wastes away with fearful rapidity— Mr Warren, and Mr Barker, strangers came together—Warren is a clergyman who went from Springfield in this State, and resides at Mobile, Alabama— He came for contribution to rebuild a Church which has been burnt there, and spoke much of the unhappy condition of the Indians, in the Southern States. I told him there were two classes of People among us; one of which sympathised with the Indians, and the other acted against them: and that it would be so till the Indian race shall be extinct— They will continue to be pitied, and exterminated— I was myself one of the sympathisers; but all I had been able to do, was to stay for a short time the exterminating hand and to pay the Indians as liberally as I could for the lands taken from them. Mr Warren thought something would be done for protection of the Indians at the next Session of Congress— Proof that he knows little of the composition of that body. Deacon Savile, spoke of a fence between his Land and mine, which I promised to view with him tomorrow. Mr Webster called on his way to Scituate, where he was going to fetch back to Boston, his children, who have passed the Summer there. Mr Martin was a visitor for curiosity— I worked this morning an hour with the Spade, and am convinced there is no better exercise for my health—but the labour is grievously irksome. Abigail S. Adams came to spend a few days with us; and this afternoon I went with her, and her brother to Genl. Dearborn’s at Roxbury— I took with me, most of the seeds and Chesnuts, sent me by E. Wyer from Smyrna, and which I desired Genl Dearborn to present in my name to the Horticultural Society, of which they have lately made me an honorary member— Mrs Dearborn was ill; confined to her chamber, but we saw their daughter Julia— We returned early in the Evening. Mr Marston had last Evening a fire; and General Dearborn told me he had one this morning.— I wrote this day scarcely a line but my Journal, and read but a very few pages.
10. IV:30. Thursday.

The weather has become so cold, particularly in the Night, that I feel sensibly the want of fires, and have great difficulty in writing. Mrs. Adams and her Son T. B. went in to Boston, and I wrote to Charles for some Books; and about some changes to be made in the fire places of my house— After breakfast I worked an hour with the Spade, which served

for the exercise of the day. President Quincy called upon me, and returned to me the draft of a Deed from my fathers Executors, which I had given him more than two months since— He left also several other papers relating to the Execution of my father’s Will; and with them my mortgage of the family mansion house and farm which we are to cancel— I spoke to Mr Quincy upon three Subjects, for his consideration and interesting to me, with reference to the University. First, respecting the donations, of Mr W. N. Boylston, and of which I told him the Executors proposed, as soon as they could command funds, to pay over to the Treasurer of the College, the principal Sums, to raise the two annuities of 100 and of 60 dollars— Secondly, I observed that as he was effecting a reform in the Administration of the Affairs of the University, I hoped he would induce the Corporation to manifest some sensibility to friendly donations— I said that nearly forty years since, my father made to the College a donation of Books— That more than thirty years since, I made a similar donation myself— That shortly after mine was made, a friend of mine advised me to claim the right of having my name affixed in the Alcove where the Books were; but I did not then think it worth while— And my father never claimed it during his life time— I now should wish him to enquire into the matter, and if according to the usage we were entitled to have our names in the Alcoves they should be placed there— I believed that this attention was due from the Government of the Institution, and that they had already lost much by the neglect of many benefactions— He said he was convinced of it, and that for the last twenty years there were no Records, and for the last four or five no accounts— That Mr Bowditch, and Mr Francis had plucked the College from the fire. He promised immediate attention to my remarks, and faithful enquiry. He said he had just had the name of Elliot put up in an Alcove, for the donations of the late Samuel Elliot and his two Sons. Thirdly, I spoke to him of the decision of the College Government, excluding my Son John, and nearly one half his Class from their degrees— It told him I thought they had been harshly, and their Parents and friends unjustly treated. I had written so to President Kirkland—and I had hoped that when the second degrees were conferred upon the Class they would have been restored to their places, but was disappointed. I now wished him to review the proceedings of the College Government on that occasion, and to do what he should think right, with regard not only to my Son John—but to all the members of his class who had been excluded from their degrees. He promised that he would— He said it had been a Government of favoritism, but should be so no longer— He spoke of the appointment of a Tutor, and said he had been solicited by a particular friend in behalf of one of his relations, but had preferred a young man of higher standing for Talents and Scholarship. He mentioned other points, upon which he had straitened the discipline of the College, and said there was an excellent Spirit prevailing among the Students— Mrs Edward and Miss Catherine Thaxter visited us this afternoon— Abigail S. Adams went to tea at Coll. Quincy’s— I went over with Farrar, to view the Fence on the Hill between Deacon Savile’s land and mine. It needs repairing, and I had much conversation with the Deacon about our respective shares of the work— Of which I agreed to do the half— T. B. Adams junr. brought me out an answer from Charles, with some books, and a form of a Deed from the Executors of W. N. Boylston. I wrote a short Letter to Van der Kemp. Price Greenleaf was here in the Evening, and I gave him some seeds and Chesnuts.
11. IV. Friday.

Being without interruption this day, I found it escape from me, and at its close that I had written little, if any thing more than usual— Instead of a Letter, I wrote nearly two pages of Memoirs but could read very little— I worked an hour with the Spade— Elizabeth C. Adams came and dined with us— There was an Evening tea-party at Mrs Charles Miller’s—which I attended— T. D. and P. Greenleaf Mr Whitney, Mr Marston, G. W. Beale, Coll. Quincy, Dr Woodward, Mr Gourgas, and Edward Miller were there, and upwards of twenty Ladies. My brother was detained at home—having applied leaches to his eyes—but his Son T. B. came in late, having been to Salem to dine— Louisa Foster, went with my brother’s two daughters, and stayed to pass the night with them. I read only a few pages of Hutchinson’s 3d. Volume; but they contained the Account of his controversy with the House of Representatives and Council of Massachusetts-Bay in February and March 1773. upon the Power of the British Parliament in the Colony. I met a few days since among my father’s papers a short note from Samuel Adams without date, but having reference to this dispute; and written while it was in progress. Hutchinson says that the papers of the House were written by Samuel Adams and Joseph Hawley; with the assistance of John Adams, though not then a member of the House— This Note of Samuel Adams shows that at the composition of the House’s reply to Hutchinson’s long Speech of February 1773. Hawley was absent— I asked Mr Marston this Evening if he had read the third Volume of Hutchinson— He said he had, and that it had roused his indignation— He thought it ought to be reviewed, and told Coll. Quincy that his Grandfather would have thrown it into the fire.
12. IV. Saturday.

Louisa C. S. Foster, returned here from my brothers, and Lieutt. T. B. Adams jr. passed the day with us. My only exercise was one hour of spading, and if I can persevere in this, I shall need no other in fair winter till the hard frosts. Josiah Adams junr. was here this afternoon; and I spoke to him to put up Book cases in the house where I now reside, in my bed-chamber— I have a Library, packed up in Trunks and Boxes in Boston; of which I have scarcely ever had the use, and which I have now no place for putting up. I intended to have built an house for that purpose, but find myself destitute of the means— My next design was to build in my yard a small Office of Stone, which I might use for a Library and Study; but even this must be postponed for the present. I have determined to turn my Bed-chamber to those uses, and before incurring any expenses which must prove burdensome, to cling to the fragment of the wreck yet left me, and await the final dispensations of Providence, concerning me and my family— I engaged Mr Adams, to procure 1000 feet of Pine, boards, and up to fit up Book cases all round my bed-chamber— I also desired him to examine the house, and report to me such repairs as may be necessary to put it in good tenantable condition— He is to commence upon the work in the course of the next week.
I sent this morning to the Post-Office a Letter to my father’s old friend Van der Kemp, in answer to one I had lately received from him— And John brought me back a Letter from J. Mappa, announcing to me judge Van der Kemp’s decease, on the 7th. instt. Monday last. I wrote one page of Memoirs; but engrossed much time in looking over the series of Laws of Massachusetts respecting Schools. It gave occasion to enquiries in my own mind, the solution of which will require much more time— In the afternoon, I resumed the examination of my fathers Journal’s of earliest date— Those which the Lieutt. is copying are of 1755 and 1756. Those which I now took up, were of 1758. 1759. and 1760 upon loose sheets of fool’s cap paper, folded to make 16 pages a sheet; written in so small a hand that they can scarcely be read without a magnifying glass, and the leaves so scattered that I could not bring them all together— I found in them much interesting matter; and some opinions of characters and things which ought never to be divulged. To arrange and copy them will still be a work of Time. I finished reading the third Volume of Hutchinson’s History, and am glad that it has been published— I propose writing some remarks upon it, and therefore say nothing further of it here.
13. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Flynt of Cohasset in the morning from 1. James 22. “But be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.” and in the afternoon from John 13.10, 11. [“]Jesus saith to him, he that is washed needeth not save to wash his feet, but is clean, every whit: and ye are clean, but not all— For he knew who should betray him: therefore said he, ye are not all clean.” Mr Flynt’s Sermons are not deficient in good sense, nor ill written; but his delivery is slow, drawling, and with a cant. His auditors in the afternoon were less numerous than in the morning— He dined with us, and I made some enquiries of him to ascertain if he was descended from Henry Flynt, the first minister of Braintree— He did not know; but said his father and Grandfather were farmers and lived at North-Reading. He said also that there were two brothers of the name of Flynt, who came with the first division of the Massachusetts Colony to Salem— And that there was a Mr Farmer of Concord New-Hampshire, about to publish a work, in which much information concerning the first Settlers of New-England will be given— I read the 10th. Sermon of Dr Freeman’s late volume on God’s regard for the poor, and the 11th. on the Joys and Sorrows of Mary; the former of which is short, and consists of obvious truths— The latter deeply and distressingly affected me— Mrs Quincy and her two elder daughters were here this afternoon, and I spent the Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleafs.
14. V:30. Monday.

After returning last Evening from Mr Greenleaf’s, and just before going to bed I was suddenly seized with a sharp pain in my left side, and upon that loin, which continued through the night and deprived me entirely of Sleep. I suppose it rhumatism— During part of the Night I had a slight fever, and in restlessness felt the Solitude of absence from all my family. This is the second night that I have passed thus within the last Month, and the suffering is in parts which admonish me to set my house in Order— The weather for the last ten days had been so cold, especially in the morning and evening that I have
shivered for want of a fire— All my neighbours have made fires; but intending to make alterations in my fire-places, and perhaps from a pride of hardihood which would have been more suitable to me thirty years since than now, I postponed it— Last Night there was a change in the weather from dry cold to damp and temperate— And I have observed it is rather moisture than cold in the atmosphere, which brings these attacks upon me— I rose this morning later than usual, and by daylight— Finding myself easier, I pursued my daily employments excepting the hour of spading which I was obliged to intermit. I finished a Letter to Dr Waterhouse, and wrote a page of Memoirs. But after dinner, I could no longer labour— The loss of the Night’s sleep, and a frequent twinge of pain, prompted me to indulge myself with a ride; and I went with Louisa C. S. Foster and Lieutt. T. B. Adams to Hingham—where we visited Quincy Thaxter, and his three daughters Eliza, Anna and Catherine— Mrs Loring, her son Thomas, and Mr and Mrs Whittemore, Mr and Mrs Thomas Thaxter, and their Son and daughter Edward and Mrs Thaxter. Also Mr Brooks the Minister, but he was not at home. We had not time to call upon Mr Gay— On returning home we found Mr James H. Foster, who had come out for his daughter Louisa, and she returned with him— My brother and his two daughters were here on their way to visit Mr T. Greenleaf— Foot-bath for my rhumatism.
15. V. Tuesday.

I was suffering all this day, with the rhumatism, and a severe Cold but having slept the last night was more able to employ this morning in writing— Wrote a short Letter to A. B. Johnson of Utica and then about a page of the Memoirs, besides copying into them the Letter from my father to Nathan Webb of 12. October 1755. A Letter in the Analysis of which I find so much matter for commentary that a sober judgment must be called in to curb enthusiastic admiration— I propose to give the Letter entire, for it is the foot of Hercules— Nothing that my father ever wrote in the subsequent course of his life, bears in more indelible characters the stamp of his genius and of his heart— Webster and Wirt have both spoken of this Letter, with high commendation; but neither of them has noticed the part of it which is most deeply affecting to me its encomium, tender and sublime, upon friendship. If I should say that the annals of epistolary correspondence cannot furnish a Letter more replete at once with intellect and heart, I should commit no excess. But I shall endeavour to keep myself largely within the bounds of moderation— After dinner, I worked about an hour with the Spade. I sent into Boston, for my Son Charles, and his wife, who came out to pass the Night with us. He brought me a Letter from John of the 9th— My dear wife has again been very ill; he says she is much better. Her sufferings distress me deeply; would that I could contribute more effectually to their alleviation— Charles brought me also a Letter, and three Volumes of Newspapers from Dr Waterhouse— General Dearborn, and his daughter Julia, paid us an afternoon visit. The General left for my perusal two Volumes of Manuscript; upon the Grecian orders of Architecture, and two Volumes of a Life of Jesus Christ; all of his own composition. Abigail S. Adams stays with us for some days.
16. IV:15. Wednesday— First fire

My Son Charles and his wife returned to Boston; and he sent me out another Letter from his brother of the 11th. with one from Mr Zebedee Cook, and a ticket for the dinner of the horticultural Society next Saturday. I answered John’s Letter, and wrote a short one to Captain Samuel Angus, to send him with a copy of Mr Monroe’s Letter to me concerning him of 25 March 1825. the original of which is on the files of the Navy Department; and of which John has sent me a copy certified by the Chief Clerk of that Department. Deacon Spear called upon me to repeat the request of a resurvey of the woodlot the title of which is in question between the Estate of my father and that of my Uncle Peter— He thinks the Season has now come in which it can be most easily effected. I promised to give attention to it. There was a sprinkling of rain all the morning, which became steady in the afternoon, and continued all the Evening—and the weather was so cold that we had a fire in our dining room. I am yet suffering with my rhumatism, and am losing the use of my right-hand for writing. With extreme difficulty, I wrote a page and a half of Memoirs; read a Chapter of Pitkin’s History of the United States, and several Sections of Cicero’s Treatise upon Friendship, with the French Translation of Barrett— I have found among my father’s paper the first sheet of his original draft of the Essay upon the Canon and Feudal Law, which I compared with a printed copy of it— The variations are inconsiderable. T. B. Adams junr. and his Sister Abigail S. remain with us.
17. V. Thursday.

Abigail S. Adams left us this morning. Her brother passed the day with us. Mr Apthorp paid me a morning visit; but being in my nursery at work when he came I did not see him. Mr Degrand came out from Boston this afternoon— When he first came I was again in the Nursery; having divided my task of exercise into two parts; forenoon and afternoon, about three quarters of an hour each. I wrote to my wife, and enclosed for her to sign and Seal, a Deed of Half an Acre of Land at the foot of Penn’s Hill to Samuel Curtis; having executed it this morning myself. Of this deed I keep a Copy in a blotting book— I gave my Son Charles yesterday, powers to receive dividends for me at the State Bank, and the Boylston Market— He brought me also a Petition to Judge Hall of the Probate Court, Boston, from the Executors of Ward N. Boylston, for Letters of Administration de bonis non, of the Will of Thomas Boylston, which was already signed by Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston, and which I signed— And a Letter from Amory Conant my Tenant at Weston, announcing that he shall give up the farm, at the expiration of the year, because its proceeds will not enable him to pay the rent. But Charles said he would probably renew the lease for five years if I would allow him to expend half the rent on the improvement of the farm; which I told him was the best thing I could do. I received this day a Letter from W. B. Hodgson, at Algiers, with a Dissertation upon the Tuarycks a Tribe of the Berbers in Africa; which he requests
me to transmit to Mr Duponceau at Philadelphia— I wrote with difficulty little more than a page of Memoirs; and read only a few Sections of Cicero de Amicitia. Spent the Evening at Mr Edward Miller’s; with the usual Quincy Society; about 12 men and 25 Ladies. There was music; and dancing by the Piano. I met there George H. Apthorp, who with his brother, William P. Apthorp took degrees last week at Yale College. They have both destined themselves for the episcopal church—for which William is going to fit himself at Princeton, and George first at Andover, a year, and then at the Theological School at New-Haven.
18. V:30. Friday.

Deacon Spear called, and brought a plan of Owen’s field, surveyed by Seth Turner junr. in December 1805 by order of a Committee of the Towns of Quincy, Braintree and Randolph, which may be of use in ascertaining the bounds between the Woodlots that were my fathers, and that which was his brother Peter’s.— The Deacon is anxious to have the new survey made Mr Webster was here this afternoon, with Mr Upham; the late Collector of the Customs at Portsmouth New-Hampshire, removed by the present President. I worked half an hour, in the Nursery this morning with the hoe; easier labour than the spade, and I spent nearly three hours in assorting the loose Sheets of my father’s Journal; which I effected, I believe I effected as nearly as it can be. I read many pages of these Journals, written at different periods of life; and became acquainted with several incidents of which I had never heard before. Towards Evening I walked across the hills, and stopped at Mr John Greenleaf’s; to enquire of Mrs Greenleaf, some particulars of her father’s life. She brought down a bundle of old papers containing the rough drafts of many of her father’s Letters, and Letters from some of his friends and relatives to him—among them one from his brother William, written in 1746. when he Richard was in Plymouth Sound, on board of the Wilmington, the vessel in which he came to this Country. He landed at Boston in November 1746— The account of his several employments and residences, from that time, till he came to Braintree in April 1775 is still imperfect; but I expect to make it out with sufficient accuracy— I was not a little diverted at finding among the old Letters, one from Nathan Webb to him, dated at Middletown 1757, in which the beautiful paragraph upon Friendship, of my father’s Letter to Webb written in October 1755, is copied verbatim and given by Webb as his own— I wrote a short Letter to P. S. Duponceau to enclose to him Hodgson’s Dissertation upon the Tuarycks, and read a few pages of Pitkin and a few Sections de Amicitia.
19. V. Saturday.

Rode to Boston with T. B. Adams junr. and his Sister Abby. I stopp’d at Mr Withington’s, at Dorchester; but he was not at home. At the Stone Cutter’s in Boston, I found Mr Cary at work, upon the monumental Inscription, for my father and mother— The tablet is of white marble six feet long, and four feet wide. It is to be put up in length horizontally, and its width perpendicular—divided into two Columns; one for my father and one for my mother— Mr Cary had copied on a paper covering a Board of the size
of the Tablet, a part of the Inscription which I had left with him; and the effect appeared to me to be good. He had already marked in pencil the dedicating initials D.O.M. upon the Stone— I noticed however several corrections to be made in the inscription—especially of the punctuation. I desired Mr Cary to complete the copy of the Inscription, upon the paper over the board, and then to send me an exact copy of that, so that I may have an opportunity of correcting any error, and preventing its transmission to the Stone— At my Son Charles’s Office, I met a Mr Grinnell of New-Bedford, who had left at my house yesterday a Letter, containing a question respecting the Construction of our Commercial Convention with France— I answered the question, but advised him for more certainty to address the same enquiry to the Secretary of State— I received several Letters, among which one from my dear and afflicted wife of the 14th.— I called at Mr Webster’s and at Judge Davis’s; but neither of them was at home— At Mr James H. Foster’s, and saw most of the family. I sent Mr Zebedee Cook jr. an answer declining to dine with the horticultural Society, at this their first anniversary, and I dined with Charles and his wife. Just before dinner Mr J. Silvestre Rebello, came in with a Mr Foster, Vice Consul of Brazil. Mr Rebello was lately the Brazilian Charge d’Affaires, but has been recalled, and has presented his Successor Mr Ribeiro to the President. He had been out this morning to Quincy to take leave of me, and told me that he had come from Baltimore here only for that purpose— A white compliment— He goes for Baltimore on Monday; there to embark for Brazil. He had been appointed Minister to the Republic of Colombia; but says another person has been appointed in his place; and that he has some questions to settle with the Treasury Department of his country. After dinner, there came a Mr Ward Litchfield, Agent for the New-England Soap-stone manufactory— I went with him to his Shop in Charlestown Street, and inspected several models of reduced Chimney fire-places. Then called upon Judge Hall, and spent an hour with him and his wife—returned to Charles’s, and thence with the Lieutenant and his Sister home to Quincy— I found Mr G. W. Beale, with his Son and daughter at my house, but they soon went away. Northern Light and cold.
20. V. Sunday.

Sun rose at the Solstice, visible obliquely from the South-eastern window of my bed chamber, just South of the corner of the Barn— From the East Southern window, it rises behind the barn— My Chronometer is just an hour in advance of the Sun. Heard Mr Whitney, this morning from Mark 4.24. “And he said unto them, take heed of what ye hear.”—and in the afternoon one of the series of discourses upon the difficult passages, in the New Testament, from 2. Peter 3.16. “In which are some things hard to be understood.” The morning Sermon was Unitarian; he said that the text 1. John 5.7. was given up by enlightened Trinitarians as spurious— I have heard and seen this often asserted by unitarians; but have not met with such admission in any enlightened Trinitarian writer— Horsley defends it as Massillon defends the Massacre of Saint Bartholomew’s. Mr Whitney said also that Griesbach a Trinitarian, had ascertained that the text Revelation 1.11. I am Alpha and Omega, was spurious— He said that James the first’s Translators of the Bible had only twenty manuscripts; and that since that time upwards of two hundred older manuscripts had been collated, which had proved the disauthenticity of many texts of the present English Bible— The afternoon Sermon handled the difficulties of the gospel of John; and gave a very short account of this Evangelist; but very superficial—
There was a child baptised by the name of Charles Lowell— I read two Sermons in Dr. Freeman’s Volume—the 12th. upon Candour and the 13th. upon the enticement of Sinners— The characteristic of these discourses is plain Sense— The duties of common morality— The Truths presented in them seem to me almost too obvious. Perhaps they are not so for the Readers for whom they were composed— Who shall say any thing new upon the duties of man?— I answered my wife’s Letter received yesterday—. Abby and Elizabeth Adams called here towards Evening, and went hence to Mr Beale’s, to make a concert of sacred music. I thought this idea might be improved upon— Visionary— T. B. Adams came, and stays the Night here— Steady rain came on at Night.
21. V. Monday.

After a rainy Night we had a day of sultry Summer heat, and advancing in age, the mind and body are more and more affected by Skye influences— Mr Noah Curtis the Town and Parish Treasurer called on me this Morning to enquire, if I had got the Deed ready; of the land I have sold to his Son Samuel— I told him I had sent it to Washington to be executed by my wife. I had a long conversation with Mr Curtis; in which I gave out some crude and undigested speculations on certain contingent means of improving the condition and prosperity of this town— William Spear came to enquire, if I should want him to assist in my projected surveys. His brother the Deacon had recommended him— I told him if I should want him I would send him word. Mr Marston was here this afternoon with his nephew Mr Campbell, from South-Carolina. Mr and Mrs T. Greenleaf in the Evening— William Greenleaf brought me in the Evening several old Letters, sent me by his Mother, from among the papers of her father. I wrote a short Letter to Mr Withington and about a page of Memoirs of my fathers For exercise, I worked an hour with the spade, and read only a few Sections of Cicero de Amicitia— Among the papers sent me by Mrs Greenleaf is a joint Letter from R. Cranch, and J. Adams to Miss Polly Smith dated at Germantown 30 December 1761— A Letter from J. Adams to R. Cranch at Salem, dated 27. September 1767. A Letter from my father to me, dated April 1776 one from my father to R. Cranch of 2. August 1776. and one from B. Rush to my father dated 7. Feby 1778.
22. IV:30. Tuesday

Elizabeth C. Adams stays with us— There was another great change of weather in the Night, and this day was clear and cold. Dr Reynolds was here this morning, last from New Bedford— He stated to me the present condition of their expedition for commerce and for Science to the South Seas— One vessel has sailed from New-York but is now at Stonington. A second is ready to sail from New-Bedford and Dr Reynolds himself is going in her. The Lyceum of Natural History at New-York have undertaken to give the Instructions for the Scientific part of the undertaking. A third vessel is very shortly to follow the two others. Mr Fanning is the Agent for the whole undertaking, and the Doctor now came to solicit a contribution from me. He had written me to the same effect from New-York, and I had answered his Letter declining the contribution; but he had not received my answer— He shewed me Letters from Professor De Kay, of New-York, one of them recommendatory to General Lyman. He
also read to me a statement of all the proceedings hitherto in fitting out the expedition. I told him that after my recommendation to Congress of a public expedition, and its sanction twice by the House of Representatives, and the manner in which the design had been defeated by the Senate, I did not think it advisable or perhaps proper for me to take any part in an expedition, which was altogether a private and mercantile concern, though I wished them all possible success— The Doctor shewed me also a Letter from Judge M’lean of 29. June, last, in which he announces his determination shortly to resign his Seat as a Judge of the Supreme Court of the United States—says he is fond of public life, but does not know whether he shall come into the House of Representatives or the Senate. He is preparing for himself reverses. I worked half an hour with the spade before dinner, and walked just before Evening— Left with Mr Brigham, Certificates of five Shares in the Quincy Canal, which I purchased two years since of Harvey Field, and were then transferred to me, but of which I had not taken out the Certificates in my own name— Called on Josiah Adams junr. to enquire why he had not begun upon my bookshelves— He said he had been unwell. I went to my brother’s to see his Son John Quincy who has been very badly poisoned by dogwood. He was asleep, and I only saw his mother— Mr Gourgas, T. B. Adams junr. and Abigail spent the Evening here— The Brigade Band of Musicians with permission of Mr Farrar pitched their tent for the Night, on the Hill opposite the House— I found this afternoon among my father’s papers, two collections of loose sheets of autobiography—of different periods of time; both unfinished, and neither coming down to the close of the Revolutionary War. I wrote a single page of Memoirs.
23. V. Wednesday.

The band of Musicians early this Morning struck their Tents and departed. I wrote a Letter to Mr Litchfield, the Agent to the New-England Soap-stone Company— Worked an hour with the Spade in my nursery before dinner and planted a row of apple cores, with the seeds, by way of experiment— Wrote upwards of a page of Memoirs and read a few pages of Judge Story’s inaugural Address.— After dinner I wrote again, about an hour and then walked to Captain Souther’s— He is now Chairman of the Selectmen, and of the Assessors. He was at his Mill, where I went and found him— I had with me the tax-bill, delivered me by Harvey Field; in which I am taxed for the present year, for State, County and Town tax, 69:44—and for Parish Tax 31.32 all for Real Estate— No Polls— No personal Estate or Income— The whole amount is 100:76. I enquired of Mr Souther, what was the Real Estate, for which I was thus taxed— He did not know— The tax was taken from that of the last year, and that from the tax of the year before. Deacon Spear was then Chairman of the Selectmen and assessors, and Captain Souther is to enquire of him and will inform me— The System of taxation itself is so complicated, that Captain Souther himself either does not comprehend or could not explain it to me— In the Tax-Bill, the State, County and Town-tax, are all thrown into one— The State tax is levied by an Act of the Legislature— The tax upon the whole Commonwealth for this year is 75000 dollars—of which the portion of the Town of Quincy is 198— Their portion of the County-tax is 576:34. and their Town-tax is 3881:90. The whole amount being 4656:24. The assessment is made upon a double formula of 2. Cents to 100 dollars multiplied by 28—so that the tax is 56 cents upon every 100 dollars of the valuation— I suppose the Statute-book will explain— But Captain Souther told me that, an Act of the Legislature last Winter
had trebled the tax upon Woodlands— Harvey Field told me that if I had been here on the first of May they would have taxed me for personal Estate— I asked Captain Souther whether in assessing the tax upon personal Estate they made any allowance for a man’s debts he said they did, and taxed him only for the balance left him after deduction of his debts. From the Captain’s I went to my brother’s, and found there his brother in Law Mr Charles Harrod, who gave me some Willow and Water Oak Acorns, Three Shagbarks from Illinois Some Honey Locust seeds and Jasmins. John Quincy was below, recovering but very feeble— I walked home and read a few of Madame du Deffands Letters; but after a day of sufficient exercise I find it impossible to read profitably in the Evening.
24. V. Thursday.

There was a training day for a Regiment of Militia, upon the fields behind my Houses at the foot of Penn’s Hill; but I had no inclination to behold it. I worked with the Spade upwards of an hour before dinner, wrote to my Son John, and towards Evening took an hour’s walk— Elizabeth C. Adams left us— Her brother Thomas came to pass the night here— In the Memoirs I barely copied the Letter from my father to R. Cranch of 29. August 1756— These Letters and Extracts from his Journals absorb much of my Time, and I am not sure that their insertion will be advisable— They may render the work at once too voluminous and unsuited to the popular taste— But I must proceed. I read Judge Story’s Discourse upon his Inauguration as Dana professor of Law at Harvard University, and I propose to write him a Letter concerning it. In the Evening I read several of Madame du Deffand’s Letters— It belongs probably to the effect of age upon the taste and judgment that these Letters are more interesting to me than any novel— They are records of realities— In youth it was directly the reverse— Fairy Tales; the Arabian Nights, fictitious Adventures of every kind delighted me— And the more there was in them of invention; the more pleasing they were. My imagination pictured them all as realities, and I dreamed of enchantments as if there was a world in which they existed— At ten years of age I read Shakespears Tempest, As you like it, Merry wives of Windsor, Much Ado about Nothing, and King Lear— The humours of Falstaff scarcely affected me at all— Bardolph and Pistol and Nym were personages quite unintelligible to me; and the lesson of Sir Hugh Evans to the boy William was too serious an affair. But the incantations of Prospero, the Loves of Ferdinand and Miranda, the more than etherial sprightly loveliness of Ariel, and the worse than beastly grossness of Caliban, made for me a world of Revels and lap’d me in Elysium. With these books in a closet of my mother’s bed chamber there was also a small Edition in two Volumes of Milton’s Paradise Lost, which I believe I attempted ten times to read and never could get through half a book. I might as well have attempted to read Homer before I had learnt the Greek Alphabet— I was mortified even to the shedding of solitary tears, that I could not even conceive what it was that my father and mother admired so much in that book, and yet I was ashamed to ask them an explanation. I smoked tobacco and read Milton, at the same time and from the same motive; to find out what was the recondite charm in them which gave my father so much pleasure— After making myself four or five times sick with smoking I mastered that accomplishment, and acquired a habit, which thirty years afterwards, I had much more difficulty in breaking off— But I did not master Milton— I was nearly thirty when I first read the Paradise Lost with delight and astonishment— But of late years
I have lost the relish for fiction— I see nothing with sympathy but men, women and children of flesh and blood— Madame du Deffand’s Suppers, afford me savoury food, and I was charmed this Evening with her picture of the Lucan family sending a Piano to her apartments—the father making his daughters play and sing an hour or two— Lady Stormont joining in the concert— The Piano and children being then sent home and leaving a party to sup. The visit of Dr Franklin and Silas Deane, with Mr Le Roy, is also very amusing; and her remark that all the company, were in favour of the Americans excepting herself and Mr de Guignes who were for the Court is more interesting to me than ten Volumes of Waverly’s. can Philosophy tell me why this is so?
25. III— V:45. Friday.

I awoke this morning; rose and lighted my Lamp, and found it was a few minutes short of three O’Clock. Read four Chapters in the Bible to finish the first Book of Kings; and seven Sections in Cicero de Amicitia, to finish the second reading of that— Then returned to bed, and dozed till broad daylight. I was chilled and could get no heat in bed— I betook myself to the spade in my Nursery, and dug for half an hour till driven into the house by the rain— William P. Apthorp was here yesterday; to enquire if I had occasion to purchase any old wine; but I have more than I want upon my hands. His father’s stock is for sale; and they are selling off also the family furniture— Mr Cutler the Minister of the Episcopal Church, has lived some years in the house, but has a pulmonary complaint, and is obliged to pass the Winter at the South— Elizabeth Apthorp, a single Lady of 65 is now the only remnant of that numerous and prosperous family of Apthorps remaining at Quincy— It will soon be extinct here. The families that endure, are in the humble vale— High-Life is beyond all things transitory— William told me that they found great difficulty in letting the House, because it had the reputation of being haunted— He said the rumour had originated from a woman; a Mantua-maker, who had slept in the west wing of the house; while his mother was living; and to his Mother’s having gone late at Night, to fetch something, into the room where the woman was in bed— I worked again with the Spade in my Nursery before dinner; and towards Evening walked to my brother’s House. His Son John Quincy was recovering. Mrs Adams unwell— His daughter Abigail brought me from Boston a packet of Letters sent by Charles. One from my dear wife of the 17th. one from Dr Waterhouse, and one from Alpheus Cary. I wrote myself, a Letter to Judge Story, for which I had very cogent motives; but the consequences of which are with a higher power— I intend is as introductory to a Correspondence with him, which may influence his Career, and Lectures as Professor of Law at Cambridge— But I know not how he will receive it. My experience has taught me to distrust deeply my own foresight in the relation of effects with their causes.— My father’s Letter of 12. October 1755 to Nathan Webb was the immediate occasion of my now having read Cicero de Amicitia— The Dialogue is between Laelius, and his two Sons in Law Mutius Scaevola and Fannius— Cicero tells Atticus that in his Youth, by direction of his father he frequented much Scaevola the Augur, and after his death, the Pontiff Mutius Scaevola, whom he pronounces the brightest genius and most upright Roman of his time— He adds that one day on the occasion of a violent quarrel between Pompey while Consul, and Publius Sulpicius then a Tribune of the People who till then had been his most intimate friend, Scaevola, sitting in his Hemicycle, and conversing with friends among whom Cicero was present, upon this rupture which caused great excitement in the City, repeated the purport of a Discourse, of Laelius upon Friendship, many years before; a few days after the Death of his friend Scipio— Cicero says he had retained in his Memory this narrative of
Scaevola, and as Atticus had often urged him to write upon Friendship, he thought he could not more effectually comply with this request, than by introducing Laelius as the Speaker on that subject, and writing from memory what Scaevola had reported him to have said— How ingenious and beautiful a Frame for a Dissertation! But I have no Time for further comment here.
26. V— Saturday.

Received Letters this Morning from my wife of the 21st. returning the Deed to Saml. Curtis executed by her—from P. S. Duponceau, returning W. B. Hodgson’s Letter; and one from a young man named just graduated at a College in Vermont, who proposes to enter the Mexican Army, and writes to me for advice and for information concerning that Country. I went into Boston over Milton-Hill: stop’d at Mr Withington’s going and returning. In the morning he was not at home— On my return I saw him, and he spoke doubtingly whether he could undertake my Surveys— But for that of the Woodlot of the questionable title, said if it should be fair weather he would come at 8 O’Clock next Thursday Morning. In Boston I stopp’d at Mr Cary’s Shop, and saw the Stone upon which he is carving the Monumental Inscription, in which he has made some progress— There are yet some questions respecting the punctuation to be determined— I called at Mr Savage’s Office, and at Mr I. P. Davis’s House, but neither of them was within— At Mr James H. Foster’s I saw Mrs Foster, and at Mr B. L. Pickman’s Mrs W. Smith and Mrs Pickman. Dined with Charles, and Mr P. C. Brooks was there. Before dinner I went to the Secretary’s Office at the State-House, and asked for a sight of the first Volume of the Colony Records— It was within ten minutes of One O’Clock when the Office was to be shut; I had time however to ascertain that Jerymy Adams was admitted to the freeman’s Oath on the 6th. of May 1635. and Richard Adams on the 2d. of September following. Neither of these is on the list of our Ancestors— After dinner Mr Nathl Curtis called at my Son’s to speak of the Letters of Administration we are to take out next Monday upon the Will of Thomas Boylston— He wished to write to Petty Vaughan by the Packet which is to sail next Thursday— There were questions upon the Bonds to be given upon which I promised to call upon Judge Hall to take information— I did call but he was not at home— Charles and his wife came with me out to Quincy. I received a Letter from Mr Sparks with a Copy of Grahame’s History of the Rise and progress of the United States— It is rather a History of the British Colonies in North America, which became the United States. The two Volumes as yet published contain only the History till the Revolution of 1688.
27. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Lamson of Dedham in the morning from Jeremiah 4.14. [“]O Jerusalem, wash thine heart from wickedness that thou mayest be saved how long shall thy vain thoughts lodge within thee?[”] And in the afternoon from Luke 8.15. [“]But that on the good ground are they, which in an honest and good heart, having heard the word, keep it, and bring forth fruit with Patience.” These were two moral Essays, extremely well written and well meditated— Sermons of this description are very pleasing to me; but there is an air of family resemblance among them all which colours them all with one complection. What would be the success of a Minister who should adopt the principle of giving to his discourses as much variety as possible— Who should at one time describe a scriptural character—at another discuss a point of controversy; at a third comment upon a parable; at a fourth dwell upon a point of morals— Perhaps it would
require a variety of Talent, with Genius and Learning; but such a preacher must be generally pleasing— Mr Lamson’s Sermons had no allusion to the thoughts of other men. Very little even to his texts; all was spun out from the Reflections of his own mind— Differing in this respect from a Sermon of Bourdaloue, which I read yesterday and this morning upon the duties of Parents to their children— This is the first Sermon of that celebrated preacher that I have ever read; but I think I shall read many more. He was one of the most famous preachers of the time of Louis 14. but differing much in the manner from Bossuet, Flechier, or Massillon— Bourdaloue quotes the Saints and Fathers in great profusion— His reasoning is much strengthened by quotations— His divisions of his subject are artificial and ingenious— Part of his argument from the peculiar character of the Tenets of the Romish Church, is not applicable to persons of the Protestant Churches— But much of his doctrine belongs to general morality— He urges that Parents have no right to controul the vocation of their children, and yet that Parents are the persons responsible for the vices of their children. I read also the Sermons 14 and 15. of the Volume of Dr Freeman—the first upon Irresolution, and the second upon the extent of Christ’s Kingdom. Coll. Quincy spent the Evening with us; and told us he should remove with his family next Wednesday to their Winter-quarters in Boston— Thomas B. Adams junr. and Isaac Hull Adams dined with us.
28. V. Monday.

The Morning was so cold that I found it impossible to write either in my Chamber or at the Office, till after Breakfast—but the day was one of the finest of Autumn— I went into Boston with Charles and his wife— Stop’d and left them, opposite to the South Boston Bridge. Called at Mr Cary the Stone Cutters, and gave him the final directions, respecting the punctuation of the Inscription. He said Dr Parkman and Mr William Lee had been to see it this morning. At James H. Foster’s I asked his daughter Elizabeth to go with me to Quincy. Met at Charles’s Office, Mr Nathl. Curtis, and went with him to the Probate-Office— The Letter of Administration upon Thomas Boylston’s Estate was made out in the names of the three Executors of W. N. Boylston, but the judge would not take each of them as bondsman for the others, and required two bondsmen beside— I therefore requested that my name should be struck out from the bond as one of the Administrators and signed as a bondsman for the others. Mr Curtis however thought it would be more advisable that the Letter of Administration should be in my name; and they the bondsmen; upon which we left the business unfinished, and Mr Curtis concluded to go out to Roxbury to consult with Mrs Boylston; then return again to Boston, and execute the Papers, and bring them out to me to Quincy to-morrow— I then called at Charles’s House; and thence went to Mr James H. Foster’s, and took Elizabeth out to Quincy where we arrived just before three. The man from the Agent of the Soap-Stone company, did not come out as he had promised; but Josiah Adams junr. was at work all day in my bed-chamber in putting up book-shelves. I passed the afternoon in the Office, writing to my wife; but suffered with a return of rhumatism— I find it scarcely possible to go as I had intended till the first of October before making a fire in my writing chamber— Read in the Evening some Letters of Madame du Deffand.
29. IV. Tuesday—

The morning was so cold that I was obliged to make the fire and read in the dining Room. I was prevented by the Rain from spading; and my writing was abridged— Mr Curtis came out early from Boston; and brought the bond to be executed— He and Mrs Boylston had agreed that the Letter of Administration should be taken out in my name alone; they signing the bond, which is for eighty thousand Dollars, as sureties— I executed the bond, which was already signed by them; and Mr Curtis returned with it to Boston— I wrote by him to Charles, and am to go to Boston to-morrow, to take out the Letter of Administration and write to Petty Vaughan. I received a Letter from Mrs Elizabeth De Wint, enclosing one from John A. Smith, with an Order for 500 dollars—to which Letter I wrote an answer. Steady rain from before daylight till 3 in the afternoon, the weather gradually moderating, till it cleared up warm. I then rode in the Chaise with T. B. Adams junr. to Deacon Spears; but he was not at home— Returning, I stop’d at my brother’s; but he had walked down to my house— I found Deacon Spear and his brother at French’s tavern, and told them that Mr Withington would come to resurvey the Woodlot Thursday morning at 8. Met my brother returning from my house, and he went back, and took the acknowledgment of my Deed of half an Acre of Land to Samuel Curtis. Peter Turner was here, and agreed to go upon the Survey on Thursday Morning— He wished Captain Josiah Bass; and Deacon Adams might also go; to which I assented, if he would give them notice— Josiah Adams junr was working all day; fitting up the book-shelves in my bed chamber— My Memoirs are suspended. I finished reading this morning Bourdaloue’s Sermon upon Marriage— He takes his division from Saint Augustin—considering it with reference to partnership, progeny and Sacrament— It is as a Sacrament that the Roman Catholics consider marriage as indissoluble. Bourdaloue says, that Christ instituted it as a Sacrament, shortly after being present at the Marriage of Cana. I do not perceive the Institution of a Sacrament, but I believe the indissoluble character of the marriage bond, is a powerful guard of morals. Bourdaloue speaks of the duties, the afflictions and the dangers of the married state, most of which are the same in all ages— He urges warmly the necessity of making it a religious transaction. A Sacrament—and thinks it should be contracted only by special vocation. He speaks of ill assorted matches, and discordant couples as very common— He exhorts the Ladies to exercise their influence over their husbands, in favour of Religion, and cites a compliment of Saint Augustin to a married woman of his time, assuring her that if Jupiter himself could have had such a wife she would have converted him to Christianity.
30. IV. Wednesday.

I went in to Boston this Morning in a Chaise with John Thomas who was unwell— Stop’d at the Stone Cutters, and saw Mr Dickinson; Cary was not there; but has nearly finished one side of the Inscription— I thence went to the U.S. Branch Bank—deposited there a check for 500 dollars to the credit of Mrs Elizabeth De Wint— Took a Certificate to that effect from the Cashier S. Frothingham, which I enclosed in the Letter I had already written to Mrs De Wint— At my Son Charles’s Office. I found the Letter of Administration de Bonis non, with the Will annexed of Thomas Boylston, and the other Papers from the probate-Office, relating to it— I signed the new
petition, and took it to the Probate Office, where I found only one Clerk— I then took the Certificate of my Appointment as Administrator to the Office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth, where it was authenticated by a Certificate with the Governor’s Signature, and the Seal of the Commonwealth— With this I returned to Charles’s Office; wrote a short Letter to Petty Vaughan, and enclosed it with the authenticated Certificate; with a Letter from the Executors of W. N. Boylston, and a duplicate of that of 24. August; all to be sent by the Ship Liverpool, to sail to-morrow— Mr Curtis called at Charles’s Office, and promised to send me the papers of W. N. Boylston’s Administration upon the Estate of T. Boylston. J. B. Davis called on me also at Charles’s Office, and said he wished to have some Conversation with me; and engaged to come out and dine with me next Saturday— Immediately after the Bell rang at One, John came with the Chaise, and I returned home to dine. My brother was also at Boston this day— After dinner deacon Ebenezer Adams came and spent a couple of hours with me. Peter Turner was here towards Evening— Elizabeth Foster and the Lieutenant passed the Evening at Mr T. Greenleaf’s.

Day— I now rise generally about four O’Clock, which on clear morning’s I ascertain by Orion and Sirius nearly on the Meridian in front of my South windows, and by the Great Bear full risen perpendicular in the Sky, tail downwards, obliquely from my Eastern windows— I light my lamps; read three Chapters in the Old Testament, and sometimes something else— Then repair to the Office, and write in this diary till breakfast between seven and eight— From breakfast till dinner at 2. P.M— I write Letters; a page more or less of Memoirs; take an hour or two of exercise and read miscellaneously— From three till the Dusk of Evening I do the same: receiving Visitors as they come; and sometimes riding out or walking, upon business or exercise— After tea, till 9 or 10. I pass the time in idleness, reading occasionally a few of Madame du Deffands Letters— Retire to bed usually before ten— I have more business than is pleasing, and being of small, momentary household concern it absorbs time and leaves me little for what I deem important. At the beginning of this Month my Son Charles was married; I hope and pray, well— Of what is to remain after me, this constitutes almost all that I have to hope, and in imploring again a blessing from God, I humbly hope the prayer may not be presumptuous.
